_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency - Risk Management Plan 2019 resubmission

Des Moines Terminal

RMP Executive Summary



DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Des Moines Terminal is a bulk fuel (refined petroleum) terminal facility, with above ground storage tanks and pressure vessels.  The pressure vessels accommodate the receipt of butane and store butane onsite for truck loading and for blending into gasoline which requires compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations as greater than 10,000 lbs are stored onsite.  



The regulated substance at this facility is butane.  The equipment which handles butane includes four pressure vessels and associated piping and equipment.  The pressure vessels and associated piping may contain up to 1,251,104 lbs of butane.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Des Moines Terminal has a strong commitment to worker and public safety, along with resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and contractors in design, installation, operations, and maintenance procedures.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the company's policy to notify the Polk County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM

The regulated butane storage/blending process in the facility is compliant with the fourteen (14) elements of Process Safety Management and other employee training programs, along with operating and maintenance procedures.  The process controls listed in Section 7.4e were chosen based on whether or not they were used as safeguards in the last PHA for this facility or if they were recommended from the latest PHA and installed prior to the RMP submittal.  There may be other process controls in this facility that were not identified as safeguards in the last PHA.  The facility has no "Trade Secrets".  The facility complies with the Federal and State requirements for leak detection of valves,

pumps, and flanges.  Inspections are conducted and documented to ensure the integrity of the regulated equipment.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There has been no accidental release from the butane process at the Des Moines terminal that has required reporting under the RMP rule within the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility is a non-responding facility. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



No changes are currently planned to the butane process.  As opportunities for improvement associated with the new butane process arise at the Des Moines Terminal, they will be evaluated by Magellan Midstream Partners, L.P.
